Secre

Belgia 1590 sti: Rom
16 January. To M
r
Secretary

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H. I signified in my former what comunica
o
n passed
up
o
my first meeting w
th
P Buis
. This daie he was w
th
mee againe &
entred into furder
comunication
conference / In
e g
nall
assembly w
ch
is
held at
is p
nt
by
e
States of Holland
, among other matt
r
s yt wilbe
proposed & as he think
concluded
t
Count Maurice
shall have by
privy counsell of Holland
rs
assigned, to bee continually attendant up
o
him, w
ch
will tend yn
e end to plain dissolution of
e
Counsell of
State
, For yt should seme by theyr daily
ceeding
t
they care to
mainteyne yt but for fashions sake & for an outward shew of ob
s
ving
e
Contract, wh
r
as yt is intended among
em selves,
t
matters of weight
shalbe alwaies handled apart & in
eir secret assemblyes, Moreover by
way of discowrse he signified unto mee, that yf hir
Ma
ty
shal refuse
e Souveraine
tection of these contreys, & bee more desirous to conclude
a peace w
th
e K. then to continew at
is charge & in these termes w
th
this people. there ys very likely meanes to effect yt, to hir Ma
tyes
good liking &
e Contreys contentment. For
e p
nt
State of
e king
affaires considered ther is no question in his opinion, but
t
e lib
r
ty
of conscience &
e fruition of their privileges, w
ch
are
e principall
causes
t
moved these contreys to put
em selves to armes, wilbe
accorded unto
em in as ample maner, as they have reason to request
One of
e hardest points will consist in suborning fytt
sons, by whose
interposition it may be brought into treaty w
ch
hee think
notw
th
standing
wilbe easlie compassed yf hir Ma
ty
bee
t
way enclined. The late
petition p
nte
d to
e K by
e States of
Artois
&
Hennault
will
give
do
a great
furderance to
e matter. For as I have hard & as M
r
Buis doth assure
mee a speciall cause of
Richardolts
errand into
Spaine
was to
suaide
e
[P] in their behalf to growe to a peace w
th
these
united provinces
for
t
yt was unpossible for them to continew their excessive charges
in these warres w
th
out some traffique w
th
theyr neybours.
Also to
e purpose of that wh
r
of yo
r
H heretofore hath requested to bee
certifyed from mee, to wytt as touching
e affection w
ch
is borne by this
people unto
Fraunce,
yt may please yo
r
H to und
r
stand that there are
4 or 5 of
e g
nall
states w
ch
up
o
ev
r
y good newes
t
cometh from
thens give out such speeches,
give out
in their private conventicles as yf
theyr onely salvation must come from
at K. and as yf they would p
nt
ly
fetch him hether in
cession. nev
r
theles
e farr greater
te of theyr
assembly, & for ought I can
ceave
e whole counsell of State &
e
cominalty in most places as I learne by Mons
r
Buis will acknowlege
no oth
r
to bee fyt for their protection but hir Ma
ty
what bad [
suasion]
may do in
cesse of time w
th
an inconstant people, it is [much] to be
feared, for doutles those few buisy bodies, have alwaies taken such
opposyt & offensive courses to hir Ma
ty
, that they think their sinne
to be greater then can be
doned, & in
t
respect will do their utt
r
most
endevo
r
to suppresse hir Ma
ties
autority in this Contrey: Notw
th
standing
e report of
e messenger sent hether from
[Bern],
wh
r
of I made mention
in my former,
e States are
suaded
t
there is vittuals in
e towne for a long
r
time & therfor use
e lesse speed in taking any resolution howbeit they
have dealt w
th
a marchant upon c
r
taine conditions w
ch
are accorded between
them, who hath promised to buy a quantity of Corne in
Cullen
and
to adventure by water to bring yt into
e Towne, w
ch
they think will
fol.16v
serve
e towne to supply
e p
nt
necessity, until such time as their forces by water
where
ey have assigned 12 ships of warre, may be able to bring them
furder relief, howbeyt all this is don w
th
out
e liking of their
martiall men here, who think yt unpossible to do any good. As far as I
can conjecture yt is rather to content them of
Guelders,
by seeming to do
theyr utt
r
most to save
e Towne, then for any hope
ey conceave of
good sucesse yn
e enterprise for yt is feared
t
by
e next wee shall
heare
t
e garrison hath compounded w
th
e Enemy.
Hag. Ja
n
16. 89
